collection.description:
This is continued from Journey into Mystery (vol. 1).

Journey into Mystery volume 1 was a comic that began publication in 1952 by Atlas, and although it wasn't until the eighty-third issue that Thor even appeared in comics, let alone the title, it is most often linked to his character. This is why after releasing the one hundred and twenty-fifth issue of the series in 1966 that the series changed its name to become the first volume entitled Thor. As of #407, the book was renamed The Mighty Thor (vol. 1) until #491 when it returned to simply Thor. In 1996, after 502 issues of the series the name changed back to Journey into Mystery (vol. 3) which is what it was called up until its end in 1998 with issue 521. Although these later Journey into Mystery issues (#503-521) spin out of Thor vol.1, they are not counted in the collective Thor series.

In 1998, Thor's adventures restarted with a new number one issue in Thor (vol. 2) and there they were contained until issue eighty-five when the series concluded in 2004. After that, Thor disappeared for a couple years until he returned in 2007 for his newest volume, Thor (vol. 3), which lasted for twelve issues with its restarted numbering. Marvel then published 599 comics in the collectively-grouped "Thor" series and therefore reverted the numbering back to its original Thor with issue 600. The series again returned to it's original title name " Journey Into Mystery" with issue 622. And Thor continued in The Mighty Thor (vol. 2). With the events of Marvel NOW! Thor was once again restarted as Thor: God of Thunder (vol. 1).

collection.name: Thor

collection.description:
After the special one-shot Silver Surfer that was listed as volume 2, this second ongoing Silver Surfer series began in 1987. The longest volume of the Surfer's history at 146 issues, we follow the Silver Surfer after his final escape from Earth and his return to the universe as a free spirit. The series lasted for 146 issues and was followed up with a mini-series named Galactus the Devourer some months after this series ended.

Collected Editions

  • Essential Silver Surfer Vol. 2 (#1-18)
  • Silver Surfer Epic Collection: Freedom (#1-14)
  • Secret Invasion: Rise of the Skrulls (#25)
  • Rebirth of Thanos (#34-38)
  • Infinity Gauntlet Omnibus (#34-38)
  • Silver Surfer Epic Collection: Thanos Quest (#39-50)
  • Marvel Tales: Thanos (#45)
  • Silver Surfer Epic Collection: The Infinity Gauntlet (#51-66)
  • Infinity Gauntlet: Aftermath (#60-66)
  • Doctor Strange, Sorcerer Supreme Omnibus Volume 2 (#67)
  • The Infinity War Omnibus (#67-69)
  • Inner Demons (#123, #125-126)
  • Silver Surfer Epic Collection: Inner Demons (#123-138 & -1)

Non-U.S. Collected Editions

  • Avengers Collection: Thanos (#44-45) (German)
collection.name: Silver Surfer

collection.aliases:
The All-New All-Different X-Men
The Uncanny X-Men
collection.description:
The comic that started it all for the X-Men. For the first 66 issues, the series starred the team of Cyclops, Marvel Girl, Angel, Beast, Iceman and Professor Xavier, with Havok and Polaris joining near the end of the run.

Unfortunately, due to falling sales and lack of interest for the comic, the series started publishing reprints from earlier adventures with issue #67. This kept on up to issue #93. With X-Men issue #94, the New X-Men team was brought into the comic after they had starred in their first adventure in Giant-Size X-Men issue #1. Beginning with issue #114 the descriptive "Uncanny" was added to the cover treatment but it wasn't until issue #142 that the volume's official name was permanently changed to Uncanny X-Men. The series continues in The Uncanny X-Men with issue #142.
